{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3526354,"name":"James","username":"JamerGamer789","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e19b73/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-13T19:39:40.936Z","cooked":"

Our team has logic to determine if the pivot arm is within a certain range to exit a command, but the problem is the arm may still moving or settling with the PID. What is the best way to check if the arm is within the bounds while making sure it didn’t shoot past? Is it just better pid tuning?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-13T19:39:40.936Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":67.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":491577,"topic_slug":"best-way-to-check-if-pid-is-at-setpoint","display_username":"James","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51278,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/best-way-to-check-if-pid-is-at-setpoint/491577/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3526355,"name":"James","username":"JamerGamer789","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e19b73/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-13T19:40:00.303Z","cooked":"

We are using SparkMAX motor controllers btw

Where is the PID running?
In any case, you can require the velocity to be below a threshold.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-13T19:45:02.735Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":104,"readers_count":103,"score":35.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":491577,"topic_slug":"best-way-to-check-if-pid-is-at-setpoint","display_username":"Lavi Arzi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53351,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5990 Controls/Strategy Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/best-way-to-check-if-pid-is-at-setpoint/491577/3","custom_user_title":"5990 Controls/Strategy Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3526386,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-13T20:10:26.135Z","cooked":"

A fairly nominal way is to check that both

  • Position is within tolerance of your final setpoint
  • Velocity is within tolerance around zero.

These conditions occur if and only if your system is at the setpoint, and finished settling.

If you’re using Commands, it’s usually convenient to throw these conditions in a trigger, such as
var onTarget = new Trigger(/*position is ok*/).and(/*velocity is ok*/).debounce(0.03)

The Debounce part of triggers is also helpful for this type of case: This only returns true if the value has been true for a long enough duration. In the case of an overshooting system, this is usually far too long for a debounce to help, but you can in theory increase it to something like 0.1 or 0.2 seconds, which will ensure the system doesn’t halt prematurely.

We use a simple positional tolerance and that’s usually enough. Once you adjust the motion control, you’ll rarely have overshoot. Even if you do, the motion control will generally compensate and correct it back to the setpoint.
